title: Failed De La Rue boss handed £50,000 to help find a new job
text:
De La Rue's former boss Martin Sutherland has been handed a £50,000 leaving package to help him find a new job.

The payout to Sutherland, who was ousted from the banknote printer in May after he lost the contract to print Britain's blue, post-Brexit passports to a French rival, is understood to have been negotiated with former chairman Philip Rogerson.

It comes just weeks after De La Rue cut 170 jobs at its banknote plant in Gateshead.

Pay off: Martin Sutherland was ousted as boss of banknote printer De La Rue in May after he lost the contract to print Britain's blue, post-Brexit passports to a French rival

Another 100 of its passport printing jobs are also due to disappear this autumn following the loss of the UK passport contract.

Louisa Bull, the national officer of union Unite, said: 'This £50,000 cheque for Sutherland to look for a new job is an example of an outrageous reward for failure.'

While most of the redundant workers have been left hunting for employment, De La Rue said it would give Sutherland £50,000 plus VAT 'towards outplacement fees incurred by him in connection with his departure'.

Outplacement fees are those paid to executive recruiters to help their client find another job.

Luke Hildyard, director of the High Pay Centre, said: 'For most ordinary workers, the cost of looking for work – like transport to job interviews or taking time out to research vacancies – is paid out of their own pocket, so it's difficult to see why a highly-paid former chief executive should be any different.

'It's an example of the UK's totally flawed corporate governance model.'
